Article Title: "Cock and Bull story": SEBI fines this stock investment advisory company that promised 95% returns
Article Text:
Cock and Bull story

Securities and Exchange Board of India ( SEBI ), the capital markets regulator, has levied a penalty of Rs 19 lakh on Sai Proficient Research Investment Advisory and its proprietor for a series of regulatory breaches, including deceiving investors with unrealistic promises of returns.As per SEBI notice, the stock market regulator found that Sai Proficient made false promises of returns as high as 95%, a practice strictly prohibited under its regulations. Such exaggerated assurances, designed to entice unsuspecting investors, were classified by Sebi as fraudulent and unfair trade practices, significantly eroding investor confidence in the securities market. The â‚¹19 lakh fine reflects Sebi's determination to penalize such deceptive practices and protect the integrity of the market.Dismissing the investment advisory firm's defense as a fabricated "cock and bull story" and a mere "afterthought" to escape accountability, Sebi's investigation revealed a pattern of misconduct, including non-cooperation with the inquiry and collusion with an unregistered entity to defraud the public. "Noticee submitted that she was pregnant and was in the last months of her pregnancy suffering from complications and thus, could not attend the office regularly and could not cooperate with investigation," as per SEBI's circular.The Sebi order details Sai Proficient's involvement with Shree Sai Proficient Financial Services (SSPFS), an unregistered entity operating illegally as an investment advisory service. The regulator's investigation found compelling evidence that SSPFS served as a front for Sai Proficient Research, facilitating the collection of investor funds. Transactions exceeding â‚¹4 crore were traced across accounts linked to both entities, exposing a deliberate and coordinated scheme to attract and mislead investors. Sebi explicitly stated that Sai Proficient acted "in connivance with SSPFS, using it as a camouflage to lure people into its net."Adding to the severity of the violations, Sai Proficient failed to provide crucial documentation to Sebi during the investigation. This included essential records such as Know Your Customer (KYC) details, risk profiling forms, and client agreements. Despite repeated notices from the regulator, the firm's non-compliance further exacerbated its regulatory breaches.
Article Summary: Sai Proficient Research Investment Advisory and its proprietor have been fined Rs 19 lakh. Probe revealed a pattern of misconduct, including non-cooperation with the inquiry and collusion with an unregistered entity to defraud the public. Article Title: Airbnb blocked 74,000 bookings worldwide on New Year eve in 2023, and says will follow same measures in 2024 as well
Article Text:
How Airbnb checks â€˜partyâ€™ booking

Planning a New Year's Eve party at an Airbnb? Think again. The company is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. This technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location. While implemented worldwide, the technology will specifically target the US, UK, Australia, Canada, France, Puerto Rico, Spain and New Zealand. Last New Year's Eve, Airbnb blocked 74,000 such bookings.High-risk bookings will be blocked or redirected to alternative accommodations. Short holiday getaways (one to three nights) in entire homes will also be restricted, and guests booking entire homes will be required to agree to a "mandatory anti-party attestation." "If a booking is identified as higher risk, the guest will either be blocked from booking, or redirected to alternative accommodations on the platform," the company said.Guests will also be required to accept mandatory anti-party attestation. "Guests who can make reservations will need to confirm that they understand that disruptive and unauthorized parties are not allowed on Airbnb, and they face suspension or removal from the platform if they violate this policy," said the company.Airbnb also has a 'Neighborhood Support Line' for local communities to report urgent issues, like a party in progress, at a home they believe is listed on Airbnb.Airbnb's efforts to curb disruptive parties started in 2019 with a ban on "party houses," followed by stricter measures in 2020 due to the pandemic. In 2022, the company permanently banned large parties worldwide following several violent incidents at Airbnb rentals, including a shooting in Pittsburgh that resulted in two deaths and eight injuries.
Article Summary: Airbnb is deploying anti-party technology globally to prevent "unauthorized and disruptive" gatherings during the holiday season. The technology uses machine learning to identify and block risky bookings, focusing on factors like trip length, booking timing, and distance from the guest's location.

Article Title: NPCI ends 2024 with one of the year's 'biggest good news' for Google, PhonePe and WhatsApp in India
Article Text:

The National Payments Corporation of India ( NPCI ) has a good news for Google Pay and PhonePe as it has again delayed the implementation of its 30% market share cap for Unified Payments Interface ( UPI ) apps.The deadline, initially set for December 31, 2024, has now been pushed to December 31, 2026. This marks the second time the NPCI has extended the deadline, having previously postponed it in 2022.According to a report by The Economic Times, this decision comes after discussions with industry playersâ€œThere were multiple conversations that happened with the industry participants and we believe that bringing the market cap at this point could slow down adoption of UPIâ€¦there is potential for the payment system to grow by another 10 times,â€ ET quoted a senior banker in the know.The delay primarily benefits PhonePe and Google Pay, the two dominant players in the UPI market, which together control roughly 90% of transactions. In November 2024, PhonePe processed 7.4 billion UPI payments, while Google Pay handled 5.7 billion, out of a total of 15.4 billion UPI transactions.By extending the deadline, the NPCI aims to foster continued growth and adoption of UPI while allowing major players like PhonePe and Google Pay more time to comply with the market share restrictions. After PhonePe and Google Pay, there is Paytm followed by Navi, Cred and others.The NPCI has also lifted all user restrictions on WhatsApp Pay, allowing the popular messaging app to onboard its entire user base of over 500 million onto the UPI platform. NPCI initially imposed a cap of one million users on WhatsApp Pay in 2020. The cap was gradually increased to 100 million in 2022 and has now been completely removed.The initial restrictions were intended to ensure a gradual rollout of the service and prevent strain on the banking infrastructure. However, with the UPI ecosystem now more robust, the NPCI has given WhatsApp Pay the green light to expand its reach.
Article Summary: The National Payments Corporation of India has again delayed the implementation of its 30% market share cap for Unified Payments Interface ( UPI ) apps. The deadline has now been pushed to December 31, 2026. This marks the second time the NPCI has extended the deadline, having previously postponed it in 2022. The decision comes after discussions with industry players.

Quadrantids meteor shower: What is it

The Quadrantids meteor shower , the first of the year, will peak in India on the early days of January, offering a spectacular celestial display for skygazers. The Indira Gandhi Planetarium in Lucknow is inviting the public to view the meteor shower through telescopes. The Quadrantids are known for their intensity, with up to 120 meteors potentially visible per hour at their peak.Sumit Srivastava, senior scientific officer at Indira Gandhi Planetarium said TOI. He added that the celestial display, which is expected to be the yearâ€™s most intense meteor shower, will potentially produce up to 120 meteors per hour.This celestial event, which started on December 27, will be visible to the naked eye during the early morning hours of January 3 and 4, when it's at its peak. NASA recommends viewing from a location away from city lights during night-time and early morning hours for optimal observation.A meteor shower is a celestial phenomenon that occurs when Earth moves through debris left behind by a comet or asteroid, creating vibrant streaks of light across the sky. The Quadrantids considered one of the best annual meteor showers, are known for their brief but intense peak and frequent bright fireballs. Unlike most meteor showers that stem from comets, the Quadrantids originate from the 2003 EH1 asteroid , which NASA describes as either a "dead comet" or a "rock comet.â€Srivastava added.The Quadrantids reach their peak in early January each year, but unlike most meteor showers that last for two days, their peak is brief, lasting only a few hours.NASA explains.The US space agency also noted that during the peak period, anywhere from 60 to 200 Quadrantid meteors can be observed per hour under ideal conditions.The Quadrantids derive their name from the defunct constellation Quadrans Muralis, introduced in 1795 by French astronomer Jerome Lalande. However, this constellation was later excluded from the International Astronomical Union's official list of recognised constellations.

As advancements in artificial intelligence continue to reshape digital landscapes, a troubling trend has emerged: the creation and dissemination of sexually explicit deepfake images. Over the course of a year, these platforms received over 18 million visits from Japan alone, trailing only the United States and India. The growing prevalence of explicit deepfake content has raised significant ethical and legal concerns, prompting calls for urgent action.The survey, conducted in collaboration with digital analytics firm Similarweb Ltd., analyzed traffic data from December 2023 to November 2024. The findings identified 41 websites that allow users to produce sexually explicit deepfake images by uploading photographs of individuals. These platforms, many of which launched in 2024, saw a surge in popularity alongside increased accessibility to generative AI technology.The global distribution of traffic to these sites highlights the scale of the issue:In Japan, an estimated 410,000 users accessed these sites monthly, with approximately 80% doing so via smartphones. Instructions for creating deepfake content were predominantly available in English, Russian, and Japanese, underscoring the international reach and accessibility of such platforms.The proliferation of deepfake technology has coincided with a sharp increase in explicit content creation. According to U.S.-based cybersecurity firm Security Hero, 95,820 deepfake videos were detected online in 2023, a figure five and a half times higher than in 2019. Alarmingly, 98% of these videos were of a sexually explicit nature.The creation and sharing of such content have profound implications, particularly for victims whose images are manipulated without consent. Social media platforms often serve as the primary channels for distributing deepfake content, compounding the harm by amplifying its reach.While deepfake technology is not inherently malicious, its misuse has sparked widespread concern. Experts argue that existing laws in many countries are ill-equipped to address the complexities of AI-generated content. In Japan, for instance, there are no specific legal provisions targeting the creation or distribution of deepfake pornography.Ichiro Sato, a professor at the National Institute of Informatics, has emphasised the urgent need for legislative reform. â€œLaws tailored to address deepfake technology must be introduced to protect individuals from exploitation,â€ Sato stated. He also highlighted the importance of promoting information literacy to equip people with the knowledge to recognize and combat deepfake content.Several nations have already taken steps to address the challenges posed by deepfake technology. In the United States, multiple states have enacted laws criminalizing the creation and distribution of non-consensual deepfake pornography . The European Union has also proposed regulations to hold AI developers accountable for the ethical use of their technologies.Japanâ€™s position as a major user of deepfake platforms underscores the necessity for similar measures. Beyond legislation, public awareness campaigns and educational initiatives are critical to fostering a culture of digital responsibility.

Article Title: Hacked Chrome extensions put Facebook Ads users at risk; these are the versions impacted
Article Text:
Which Google Chrome versions are impacted

Hackers have injected harmful code into several Google Chrome extensions, targeting users of Facebook Ads. Cybersecurity firm Cyberhaven revealed that the malicious extensions were designed to steal sensitive information like access tokens, user IDs, account details, and cookies. This puts Facebook Ads users at serious risk of data theft and account hacking.In a blog post, Cyberhaven reported that its own Chrome extension was hacked on December 24 in an attack aimed at social media advertising and AI platform logins. Other extensions, such as ParrotTalks, Uvoice, and VPNCity, were also impacted starting in mid-December, according to Jaime Blasco from Nudge Security, as reported by Reuters.The breach was first detected on December 25, and researchers quickly removed the harmful version of the extension within an hour.â€œOn December 24, a phishing attack compromised a Cyberhaven employee's credentials to the Google Chrome Web Store. The attacker used these credentials to publish a malicious version of our Chrome extension (version 24.10.4). Our security team detected this compromise at 11:54 PM UTC on December 25 and removed the malicious package within 60 minutes,â€ Cyberhaven said in a blog post.According to Cyberhaven, the incident was brief and limited in scope. Only version 24.10.4 of the Cyberhaven Chrome extension was affected, and the malicious code was active from 1:32 AM UTC on December 25 to 2:50 AM UTC on December 26. Chrome browsers that auto-updated the extension during this time were impacted.The company clarified, "Our investigation found that no other Cyberhaven systems were compromised." For affected browsers, the malicious code may have stolen cookies and login sessions from certain websites. Initial findings suggest the attacker specifically targeted logins to social media advertising and AI platforms.
Article Summary: Hackers have injected harmful code into several Google Chrome extensions, targeting users of Facebook Ads. Cybersecurity firm Cyberhaven revealed that the malicious extensions were designed to steal sensitive information like access tokens, user IDs, account details, and cookies. The breach was first detected on December 25, and researchers quickly removed the harmful version of the extension.
